verses.text: These are the ordinances that you must set before them:
verses.comment: God gives specific laws for Israel to follow, highlighting that faith must be lived out through obedience to God's structure. See also Deuteronomy 4:8.

verses.text: If you buy a Hebrew servant, he shall serve for six years, but in the seventh he shall go free, without paying anything.
verses.comment: This law establishes mercy and the importance of rest, as reflected in the Sabbath cycle—a foreshadowing of redemption (Hebrews 4:9).

verses.text: If he came in by himself, he shall go out by himself; if he was married, then his wife shall go out with him.
verses.comment: This law affirms both individual and family integrity in God's justice, showing His concern for wholeness within family life.

verses.text: If his master gives him a wife and she bears him sons or daughters, the wife and her children shall belong to her master, and he shall go out alone.
verses.comment: This highlights the authority structure in ancient society. In a spiritual sense, true freedom is only found in God's grace (John 8:36).

verses.text: If the servant plainly says, ‘I love my master, my wife, and my children; I will not go out free,’
verses.comment: This reflects a voluntary, loving submission, an echo of Christ’s obedience to the Father (Philippians 2:7-8).

verses.text: then his master shall bring him to God, and shall bring him to the door or the doorpost. His master shall bore his ear through with an awl, and he shall serve him forever.
verses.comment: Piercing the ear publicly declares lifelong commitment—spiritually, this prefigures the call to consecrated lifelong service (cf. Romans 12:1).

verses.text: If a man sells his daughter to be a female servant, she shall not go out as the male servants do.
verses.comment: The law protected vulnerable girls with specific stipulations. In Christ, all are called to dignity and sonship (Galatians 3:28).

verses.text: If she does not please her master, who has designated her for himself, then he shall let her be redeemed; he shall have no power to sell her to a foreign people, since he has dealt deceitfully with her.
verses.comment: Redemption and mercy are at the heart of God’s law, reflecting the deeper pattern of redemption fulfilled in Christ (Ephesians 1:7).

verses.text: If he designates her for his son, he shall deal with her according to the custom of daughters.
verses.comment: The status of the servant is elevated, pointing toward God adopting us as His children (Romans 8:15).

verses.text: If he takes another wife to himself, he shall not diminish her food, her clothing, or her marital rights.
verses.comment: Justice demands care for all parties. Even in the Old Testament, the protection of marital rights foreshadows the later understanding of the indissolubility and sanctity of marriage (cf. Matthew 19:6).

verses.text: If he does not provide these three things for her, she shall go out free, without payment of money.
verses.comment: The law upholds justice for women, an early expression of the dignity of every soul before God.

verses.text: Whoever strikes a man so that he dies must surely be put to death.
verses.comment: The seriousness of taking innocent life affirms the sacredness of life—a foundation for later teaching on the value of every person.

verses.text: But if he did not lie in wait, but God allowed it to happen by his hand, I will appoint for you a place to which he may flee.
verses.comment: The idea of cities of refuge foreshadows God's mercy and the way He provides for repentance and safety—a shadow of the grace offered in Christ.

verses.text: But if a man willfully attacks another to kill him by cunning, you shall take him even from my altar, that he may die.
verses.comment: God’s justice does not allow His altar to be used as refuge for the unrepentant, emphasizing divine justice balanced with mercy.

verses.text: Whoever strikes his father or his mother shall be put to death.
verses.comment: This command upholds the commandment to honor parents (Exodus 20:12), a family principle later highlighted in Ephesians 6:2.

verses.text: Whoever kidnaps a person, whether he sells him or he is found in his possession, shall surely be put to death.
verses.comment: The prohibition of kidnapping and human trafficking is absolute, underscoring respect for human dignity—a timeless moral law.

verses.text: Whoever curses his father or his mother shall surely be put to death.
verses.comment: Respect for one's parents is fundamental, laying the foundation for ordered society and spiritual obedience.

verses.text: If men quarrel and one strikes the other with a stone or with his fist, but he does not die but is confined to bed,
verses.comment: The law carefully weighs personal responsibility and restitution, forming the basis for later Christian social teaching (Luke 10:35-37).

verses.text: if he rises again and walks about outside using his staff, then the one who struck him shall be acquitted; he shall pay only for the loss of his time, and shall have him thoroughly healed.
verses.comment: This shows the concern for restitution and restoration—a principle lived out in the Christian community (cf. Luke 19:8).

verses.text: If a man strikes his male or female slave with a rod, and the slave dies under his hand, he shall surely be punished.
verses.comment: Even the life of a servant is protected, underscoring the value God places on every person.

verses.text: But if the slave survives for a day or two, he shall not be punished, for the slave is his property.
verses.comment: This regulation acknowledges the societal context but also highlights God’s concern for justice within fallen structures.

verses.text: When men strive together and hit a pregnant woman so that her children come out, but there is no harm, he shall be fined as the woman’s husband demands of him, and he shall pay as the judges determine.
verses.comment: Human life, even in the womb, is protected, foreshadowing the deeper Christian doctrine of the sanctity of life.

verses.text: But if there is harm, then you shall pay life for life,
verses.comment: The principle of proportional justice is established, which lays the groundwork for later teachings on both justice and forgiveness (Matthew 5:38-39).

verses.text: eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot,
verses.comment: This law of proportionality is later transformed by Christ, who calls for mercy (Matthew 5:38-39).

verses.text: burn for burn, wound for wound, stripe for stripe.
verses.comment: God insists upon fair justice, which also points to the deeper call for forgiveness in Christ.

verses.text: If a man strikes the eye of his male or female servant and destroys it, he shall let the servant go free because of his eye.
verses.comment: God requires just compensation and advocates for release in case of serious injury.

verses.text: If he knocks out the tooth of his male or female servant, he shall let the servant go free because of his tooth.
verses.comment: Release from servitude because of harm further enforces the dignity given to each person under God’s law.

verses.text: If an ox gores a man or a woman to death, the ox shall surely be stoned and its flesh shall not be eaten, but the owner of the ox shall not be held liable.
verses.comment: The law makes clear separation between accidental and intentional harm—prefiguring the later distinction between different kinds of sin (see 1 John 5:16-17).

verses.text: But if the ox has been accustomed to gore in the past, and its owner has been warned but has not kept it in, and it kills a man or a woman, the ox shall be stoned and its owner shall also be put to death.
verses.comment: The severity of this judgment reflects the responsibility to prevent evil when one is aware of danger—conscience and responsibility are essential in Christian life.

verses.text: If a ransom is imposed on him, then he shall give for the redemption of his life whatever is imposed on him.
verses.comment: Redemption through payment is permitted, reminding us of the necessity of restitution and the greater price paid for sin by Christ (1 Cor 6:20).

verses.text: If it gores a son or a daughter, he shall be dealt with according to this same rule.
verses.comment: God's justice applies to all, young and old—his law gives equal protection and responsibility.

verses.text: If the ox gores a male or female servant, the owner shall give to their master thirty shekels of silver, and the ox shall be stoned.
verses.comment: Thirty pieces of silver foreshadows the price paid for Jesus’ life (Matthew 26:15), showing the unity between the Old and New Testament.

verses.text: If a man opens a pit, or if a man digs a pit and does not cover it, and an ox or a donkey falls into it,
verses.comment: This law illustrates the need for care and accountability—preventing harm is a sign of true love for neighbor.

verses.text: the owner of the pit shall make it good; he shall give money to its owner, and the dead animal shall be his.
verses.comment: The law enforces restitution—making amends for harm done reflects both justice and the call to reconciliation.

verses.text: If one man’s ox hurts another’s, so that it dies, then they shall sell the live ox and divide the price between them; they shall also divide the dead animal.
verses.comment: Shared responsibility and equitable resolution of disputes is a principle echoed in Christian stewardship and fellowship.

verses.text: Or if it is known that the ox has been in the habit of goring and its owner has not kept it in, he shall surely pay ox for ox, and the dead animal shall be his own.
verses.comment: Greater knowledge brings greater responsibility, a theme carried into the New Testament (James 4:17).
